An
 alternative method for studying lens MIMO systems was introduced in [27],
 which treated the lens and antenna array as an integrated component.

By utilizing the energy-focusing capability of EM lenses [33], an ideal
 receiving (transmitting) lens antenna array is able to focus (steer) the arriving (departing) signals with different
 angle of arrivals (AoAs)/departures (AoDs) to (from) distinct array elements [27].

By further exploiting the fact that mmWave channels typically have small number of paths 
[3], also known as multipath sparsity, it has been shown that the number of
 required RF chains for capacity-achieving performance in mmWave lens MIMO systems only depends on the number of signal
 paths, rather than that of antenna elements employed [27].

Moreover, for lens
 arrays with sufficiently large angle resolution, the detrimental inter-symbol interference (ISI) for wideband
 communications over frequency-selective channels (as typically the case for mmWave systems) is inherently mitigated
 since the multipath signals are separable over the arrays, thanks to the AoA/AoD-dependent energy focusing 
[27] of the lenses.

As a result, the low-complexity single-carrier (SC)
 modulation applied over parallel flat-fading channels is in principle capacity-optimal, a technique termed as path
 division multiplexing in [27].

As shown in Fig. 2, a lens antenna array is in general composed of an EM
 lens with energy-focusing capability and a matching antenna array with elements located in the focal region of the
 lens [27].

The frame structure of LAA is mostly inherited from that of licensed band LTE except some disparities introduced to support flexible start and end of DL burst caused by LBT operation. 1) Reservation signal: If the starting point of a DL burst after random backoff is not aligned with subframe boundary, eNB can generate a reservation signal (RS), which is a dummy signal used to grab the channel, until the next upcoming subframe boundary. 2) Maximum channel occupancy time: A DL burst including reservation signal should not exceed maximum channel occupancy time (MCOT), which is defined per channel access priority class [8]. 3) Initial and ending partial subframes: In order to reduce reservation signal overhead, LAA introduces the concept of initial partial subframe (IPS) which allows LAA to start an actual data transmission at the center of a subframe.

\$t_{S}\$

\$V_{O}\$

\$\Delta V_{\mathrm {US}}\$

context.text: Previous works [5]–[7][8] have reported controllers for multiphase buck converters to provide fast load-transient response.

However, the controllers in [5]–[7] cannot instantly detect large and rapid 
\$\Delta I_{\mathrm {load}}\$
 due to the inherent delays of the pulse width modulation (PWM) trigger [5], [6] or hysteresis controller [7].

Moreover, the controllers in [6] and [7] cannot instantly enable all phases to handle large and rapid light-to-heavy 
\$\Delta I_{\mathrm {load}}\$
 due to the employed slow-response active phase count (APC) technique, which disables some phases at light loads to maintain high efficiency over a wide load range.

Furthermore, the controllers in [5]–[7][8] are not able to accurately control the charging 
\$T_{\mathrm {ch}}\$
 and discharging 
\$T_{\mathrm {dch}}\$
 durations of the output inductors during load transients; as such, their load-transient responses cannot be optimized.

In [5]–[7], the theoretical minima of the 
\$\Delta V_{\mathrm {US}}\$
, 
\$\Delta V_{\mathrm {OS}}\$
, and 
\$t_{\mathrm {S}}\$
 are not available since 
\$\Delta I_{\mathrm {load}}/\Delta t_{\mathrm {load}} < \Delta I_{\mathrm {Lo}}/\Delta t\$
.
